title: QuickQuid customers who were mis-sold loans promised 'quick and easy' compensation
text:

QuickQuid customers who believe they may have been mis-sold loans are being told they'll soon be able to apply for "quick and easy" payouts for the lender's bad practices.

But compensation will be "just a fraction" of what would have been owed this time last week - before the firm withdrew from the UK and went into adminstration.

Borrowers who believe they were mis-sold a loan by collapsed payday lender QuickQuid will need to apply for compensation via an online portal, the company's administrators, Grant Thornton, said.

The portal is not yet live, but is expected to be similar to the claims service for ex-Wonga customers, which saw 389,621 eligible claims after its collapse in 2018.

QuickQuid's owner, US-based Enova, last week announced plans to close its UK business on the back of "regulatory uncertainty".

On Friday, the firm officially crashed into administration.

At the time of its collapse, the Financial Ombudsman said it had 3,000 outstanding complaints from customers.

Administrators Grant Thornton have now warned that compensation for successful claims would be "considerably smaller" than would have been the case before the lender's collapse.

The amount actually paid out from an eligible claim will be calculated when the company's assets are sold.

Others, who believe they may have been mis-sold loans and have yet to make a claim, will eventually need to apply via the online portal.

These will be assessed using criteria agreed with the Financial Ombudsman.

"This is because it is expected that the total value of all accepted claims received will significantly exceed the money available to be shared out," the administrators said.

Those affected are also being invited to call customer support on 0800 056 1515 if the loan is with QuickQuid or 0800 210 0923 if the loan is with On Stride, but be aware that lines are expected to be busy.

QuickQuid is one of the brand names of CashEuroNet UK, which also ran On Stride - a provider of longer-term, larger loans and previously known as Pounds to Pocket. All have now stopped lending and are part of the administration process.

Payday lender, The Money Shop, also closed earlier this year, making the third in just over 12 months.
description: Borrowers who believe they were mis-sold a loan by the collapsed payday lender will need to apply for compensation via an online portal
